channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Colombia Live Updates: Gustavo Petro Elected the First Leftist President
item.description: A former rebel and a longtime legislator won Colombia’s presidential election on Sunday, galvanizing voters frustrated by decades of poverty and inequality under conservative leaders.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Preserving the Music of Morocco’s Sephardic Jews
item.description: For centuries after the expulsion from Spain, Morocco’s Sephardic Jewish women sang of love, loss and identity. Now, they’re almost all gone.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Seif Kousmate for The New York Times
item.media:description: A prayer songbook in Vanessa Paloma Elbaz’s office in Casablanca, Morocco.

item.title: The ‘Hard Yakka’ of Defining Australian English’s Many Quirks
item.description: It took a while for Australians to appreciate their linguistic distinctiveness. The editors at the Australian National Dictionary Center work to document it.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amanda Laugesen at the Australian National Dictionary Center in Canberra.

item.title: French Election: Macron’s Coalition Expected to Prevail, but Will Be Weakened in Parliament
item.description: In crucial vote, the French president was projected to lose the strong majority he needed to push through his domestic agenda, a setback for his second term.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Voting in the second round of the French parliamentary elections in Le Touqeut on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Ukraine Rushes Reinforcements to Sievierodonetsk
item.description: As Russia pummeled eastern Ukraine with strikes, losses were climbing for both sides in a grinding war that Western leaders warned could last years.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Boris Johnson Defends Britain’s Plan to Electronically Monitor Refugees
item.description: A new British government program would fit some asylum seekers with GPS trackers, drawing condemnation from refugee rights organizations who say they are being treated like criminals.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees picked up in the English Channel were brought ashore by the U.K. Border Force at Dover, England, last year.

item.title: Declaring Curry and Samosas Enemy No. 1 to Whip the Police Into Shape
item.description: The police chief in an Indian island territory had a theory: If the boss was watching his officers’ weight, they would too.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officers eating a meal in a police van in Port Blair, the capital of the Indian island territory of Andaman and Nicobar.

item.title: Ukraine’s Death Workers: ‘If You Take It All Close to Heart, You Go Mad’
item.description: The people toiling in Ukraine’s cemeteries and morgues bear a silent burden as they handle the war’s growing toll.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a man who was killed in the Donetsk region, at the Lychakiv cemetery in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Attack at Sikh Temple in Afghanistan Kills Several People
item.description: The assault in the capital, Kabul, was the latest in a series targeting the country’s religious minorities that have stoked fears about the Taliban’s ability to provide security.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Ahmad Sahel Arman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Taliban fighter standing guard outside a Sikh temple that was attacked on Saturday morning in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Death in Ukraine: A Special Report
item.description: From battlefields pockmarked by artillery shells to basements and backyards filled with civilian corpses, the war has exacted a staggering toll in lives lost. New York Times reporters who have covered the war present accounts of the many ways that death arrived in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times

item.title: Russians Breached This City, Not With Troops, but Propaganda
item.description: As they batter towns and cities in Ukraine with artillery, the Russians are also bombarding them with messaging aimed at eroding Ukrainians’ trust in their military and their government.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Colombia Will Soon Have Its First Black Female Vice President. Will It Be Her?
item.description: A few months ago, Marelen Castillo was a top director of a Catholic university. Now, she is one of two Afro-Colombian women who could become the country’s next second in command.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Castillo has kept her message centered on improving public education and increasing economic opportunities, particularly for women.

item.title: Chie Hayakawa Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
item.description: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chie Hayakawa in Tokyo. Her new film “Plan 75” takes on one of the biggest elephants in the room in Japan: the challenges of dealing with the world’s oldest society.

item.title: Opposition Surge Weakens Macron’s Absolute Majority in French Parliament
item.description: For the first time in 20 years, a newly-elected French president failed to win an absolute majority in Parliament, forcing President Macron to deal with a defiant left and a resurgent far-right.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Michel Spingler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron voting on Sunday in Le Touquet, France.

item.title: Before He Ran for President, Gustavo Petro Was a Guerrilla Fighter
item.description: Petro belonged to M-19, born in 1970 as a response to alleged fraud in that year’s presidential elections. It was far smaller than the country’s main guerrilla force, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro last month in Santa Marta, Colombia.

item.title: Gustavo Petro Wins Colombia’s Presidential Election
item.description: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro at the end of the first round of presidential elections in Bogotá last month.

item.title: Paul Haggis Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges in Italy
item.description: Haggis, who wrote and directed the Oscar-winning crime drama “Crash,” was accused of assaulting a woman in Ostuni over the course of two days.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Daniele Venturelli/Getty Images
item.media:description: Paul Haggis, who was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in Southern Italy. “He is totally innocent,” his lawyer Priya Chaudhry said.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Gains in the Donbas Region
item.description: Also, France’s president lost a majority in Parliament and Colombians voted for their next leader.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers urged residents of Lysychansk, Ukraine, to evacuate on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Forces Tighten Noose Around Important Cities in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The area around Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk is about three-quarters encircled by Russians, leaving only a slender gap there for Ukrainian troops to maneuver.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Vivian Yee, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops headed Sunday toward Toshkivka, Ukraine, a small town southeast of the metropolitan area of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk. It was not clear late Sunday which side controlled Toshkivka.

item.title: Children of Ukraine’s Fallen Soldiers Spend Father’s Day in New Grief
item.description: As the war’s death toll continues to climb, families mourn the losses of fathers-turned-soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana Stepanenko and her daughter Mariia at their home in Rudne, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Over 200 Feared Dead in Ethiopia Massacre
item.description: The killings were the latest to roil the Horn of Africa nation, which is reeling from a civil war that began almost two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Eduardo Soteras/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia addressing the Parliament in Addis Ababa in June. Last week, Mr. Abiy announced the establishment of a committee to negotiate peace with the Tigrayans.

item.title: Francia Márquez Has Just Become Colombia’s First Black Vice President
item.description: Ms. Márquez’s biting analysis of social disparities cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely heard in the country’s powerful political circles.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francia Márquez, a vice presidential candidate from the mountainous department of Cauca in southwestern Colombia, has become a national phenomenon.

item.title: FINA Restricts Transgender Women From Competing at Elite Level
item.description: The international swimming federation said transgender women who had experienced male puberty could not compete in women’s events.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Joseph Prezioso/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lia Thomas, a transgender woman, swimming at the Ivy League women’s swimming and diving championships in February. The new FINA policy will bar swimmers like her from elite women’s competitions.

item.title: France’s Far Right Wins Record Number of Seats in Parliament
item.description: The party of Marine Le Pen secured enough seats to form a parliamentary group, giving it more clout, for the first time in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Forming an official group in Parliament is crucial for the National Rally, Marine Le Pen’s party.

item.title: Establishment conservatives quickly aligned with Hernández after his unexpected second-place win.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rodolfo Hernández during a campaign event this month in Barranquilla.

item.title: Germany Says It Will Restart Coal Power Plants to Save Natural Gas
item.description: It was one of a series of measures announced by Germany’s economy minister, as Europe takes steps to deal with reduced energy supplies from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Cooling towers at coal-fired power plants in Neurath, Germany, in April.

item.title: Scenes from the polls as Rodolfo Hernández and Gustavo Petro cast their ballots.
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Colombian presidential candidate Rodolfo Hernández at a voting site in Bucaramanga, Colombia, on Sunday.

item.title: As the Colombian presidential race tightens, the two candidates turn up their attacks.
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rodolfo Hernández, a presidential candidate, meeting his supporters this month in the streets of Barranquilla, Colombia.

item.title: What is Uribismo and why are Colombians voting against it?
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators holding a poster with photos of the current president, Iván Duque, left, and former president Álvaro Uribe at a protest in Bogotá last year.

item.title: Looming over the election is the rise of armed groups that threaten to once again tear Colombia apart.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebels in Putumayo, Colombia.

item.title: A Looming Threat
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has civilians in Taiwan taking China’s aggression more seriously.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians participating in a battle simulation during a combat medic training workshop near Taipei in May. Since the war in Ukraine began, a growing number of Taiwanese have been making their own preparations for war.

item.title: As Colombia votes, at stake is the fate of the third largest nation in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters cast their ballots in Colombia’s presidential election, in Bucaramanga, on Sunday.

item.title: Republican Drive to Tilt Courts Against Climate Action Reaches a Crucial Moment
item.description: A Supreme Court environmental case being decided this month is the product of a coordinated, multiyear strategy by Republican attorneys general and conservative allies.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republican attorneys want to hem in what they call the administrative state, the E.P.A. and other federal agencies that set rules and regulations that affect the American economy.

item.title: It’s Macron vs. the Left in a Fierce Battle for France’s Parliament
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s supporters and an alliance of left-wing parties came in neck and neck in the first round of voting. Now they are in a bruising face-off for control of the lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: NUPES (Nouvelle Union Populaire Ecologique et Sociale)
item.media:credit: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters
item.media:description: Candidates and supporters of the left-wing coalition Nupes at a news conference in Paris on Friday ahead of the second round of the French parliamentary elections on Sunday. The banner reads, “Generation Nupes Let’s Vote.”

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War Could Last Years, Western Leaders Say
item.description: Jens Stoltenberg said that Ukrainian forces were fighting bravely, and that with the arrival of more modern weaponry, they would be able to push Russian troops out of the eastern Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Valeria Mongelli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, at a NATO defense ministers’ meeting in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: The Odesa opera house reopens, defying Russia’s aggression.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Russia’s advances in eastern Ukraine have been costly.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian regional police force in the eastern city of Lysychansk, which neighbors Sievierodonetsk, this month.

item.title: Zelensky visits war-torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Third Man Arrested in Amazon Slayings of Journalist and Activist
item.description: The police in Brazil said on Saturday that they had arrested another person connected to the deaths of Dom Phillips and Bruno Araújo Pereira, and said the men been shot to death.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Paiva/Getty Images
item.media:description: A protest by members of the Guarani indigenous community demanding justice for Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira in São Paulo on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Visits War-Torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in Southern Ukraine
item.description: The president’s trip aimed to highlight Ukraine’s grip on the area and to lift the spirits of an embattled populace.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: A Chance Encounter Helps Return Sacred Artifacts to an Indigenous Group
item.description: The United Nations helped the Yaqui Nation, an Indigenous group in Mexico and the United States, reclaim a deer’s head and other items from a Swedish museum.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: Odesa Opera House Reopens Amid Putin’s War
item.description: War is not far away, but a city that has always lived for the moment proclaims that culture will help Ukraine prevail.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

item.title: What to Know About Covid Vaccine Doses for Very Young Children
item.description: Vaccines from Pfizer and its partner BioNTech are already been available for Americans 6 and older, and Moderna’s vaccines have been approved for adults.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vaccines from Pfizer and its partner BioNTech have already been available for Americans 6 and older, and Moderna’s vaccines for adults.

item.title: Jan. 6 Hearings Underscore Hard Truths About Democracy
item.description: When political leaders face a constitutional crisis, like that of Jan. 6, the process of collectively deciding how to respond can be messy, arbitrary, and sometimes change the nature of the system itself.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the January 6th select committee during the third select committee hearing on Capitol Hill, on Thursday.

item.title: Summer Begins
item.description: The season is almost here, finally, with all its sun-dappled splendor and glorious clichés.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Deaths of Russians In Ukraine Are Veiled in Secrecy
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of a Russian soldier near Kharkiv, Ukraine, in February.

item.title: The Battlefield in Ukraine: A Kaleidoscope of Death.
item.description: Some of the most lethal weapons ever used have been unleashed on both sides in appalling quantities: cluster rockets, self-detonating mines, battle tanks, howitzers, thermobarics and incendiary munition.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Shadow Looms Over Fading Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: With no compromise in sight and Iran making steady progress toward nuclear capability, the Biden administration could soon face a stark choice.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Lara Jakes
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Natalie Behring for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump withdrew in 2018 from the nuclear pact brokered with Iran by the Obama administration.

item.title: Congo Closes Its Rwanda Border After Soldier Is Killed
item.description: The incident comes as tensions between the two countries have escalated in recent weeks, threatening to destabilize an already volatile, mineral-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Esdras Tsongo/Reuters
item.media:description: The border crossing between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo in Goma was closed Friday after a Congolese soldier was killed by a Rwandan police officer.

item.title: British Journalist Dom Phillips’s Remains Identified, Brazil’s Police Say
item.description: The remains of a second person, believed to be Bruno Pereira, who disappeared with Mr. Phillips in the Amazon on June 5, were still being analyzed.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Joao Laet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The veteran foreign correspondent Dom Phillips, seen here in Brazil in 2019, disappeared in the Amazon while working on a book.

item.title: Toronto Blue Jays’ Manager By Day, Salsa Musician By Night
item.description: Growing up in Puerto Rico, Montoyo learned to play percussion and salsa music.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Brendan George Ko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charlie Montoyo, the manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, making music.

item.title: A Defiant Putin Says Russia Will Flourish Without the West
item.description: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Anatoly Maltsev/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A large screen showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum on Friday.

item.title: Foreign Fighters in Ukraine Face Perils if Captured
item.description: Thousands of foreign fighters have gone to fight for Ukraine, but not all join its International Legion. Russia has maintained that some of foreign fighters it has captured are mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign fighters in Ukraine, whether they have joined the country’s International Legion or one of the loosely organized outfits around the country, face the prospect of hostile treatment if captured by Russian forces, in addition to the obvious perils faced by Ukrainian nationals who have joined the fight.

item.title: Internal challenges like corruption pose challenges in Ukraine’s bid to join the E.U.
item.description: The rules for joining the European Union require candidate nations crack down on corruption, a problem that Ukraine has struggled to address, including since President Volodymyr Zelensky took office.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although Ukraine has won over many Europeans in its campaign for E.U. membership, it might face a long road of internal reform before joining the bloc.

item.title: Fuel-Starved and Stuck in Crisis, Sri Lanka Orders Work from Home
item.description: The decree applies to employees of the state and education sectors, and was aimed at reducing the rush to public transport in the nation of 21 million.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Chamila Karunarathne/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A line for fuel in Colombo on Friday.

item.title: Russian Spy Stopped From Infiltrating the ICC, Dutch Intelligence Says
item.description: Sergey Vladimirovich Cherkasov spent years building an identity as a Brazilian citizen, polishing a résumé that got him an internship at the court, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague

item.title: Here is what to know about the Covid vaccine for infants and toddlers.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Matt Chase; Photograph By Getty Images

item.title: Paolo Macchiarini, Star Surgeon, Loses Court Ruling in Sweden
item.description: Dr. Paolo Macchiarini became a star by creating a “bioartificial” windpipe. But it did not work, and a court in Sweden has found him criminally liable for the harm inflicted on a patient.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Christina Anderson

item.title: Greek Court Rejects Effort to Toughen Punishment After Killing of an American
item.description: Bakari Henderson, a college graduate from Texas, was beaten to death in a resort area in July 2017. The court on Friday upheld the original convictions.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Giannis Androutsopoulos/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jill and Phil Henderson, front, the parents of Bakari Henderson, outside the courthouse in Patras, Greece, in November 2018, when the original verdict was handed down.

item.title: Boris Johnson Pays a Second Surprise Visit to Kyiv
item.description: Boris Johnson promised new military aid that would train up to 10,000 Ukrainian soldiers every 120 days.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via AFP
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, left, paid a surprise visit to President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Egypt, America’s Middle Eastern ally, maintains warm relations with Putin.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Johanna Geron
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt has tried to balance his country’s relationship with both Russia and the United States, from which it has received billions of dollars in aid.
